references: There exists minuscule number of research publications focused exclusively on providing an overview of the use of FL in IDS. But there does exists quite a number of surveys focused on FL and IDS separately though. Hence in order to fill this gap, the present paper intends to provide a comprehensive survey of the FL technique applied to IDS. It is highly expected that the discussion and exploration could give scientific and technical readers an overall understanding of this domain and foster more subsequent studies on this issue. The earlier efforts are summarized in Table I. In this section, the main contributions of the various works in this field are presented which helps to compare the same with our contributions.

references: As illustrated in Figure 2, the rest of this paper is organized as follows. In section II we give a summary of IDS, as well as the role of machine learning and artificial intelligence (ML/AI) in anomaly intrusion detection. The main purpose of section III is to provide a comprehensive survey of FL applications with anomaly-based Intrusion Detection Systems. This survey also highlights open challenges and issues of using FL for IDSs as presented in section IV. Next, section  V discusses future research directions for FL-based intrusion detection. Finally, section VI outlines the conclusions of this paper. For the purpose of better comprehension, the definitions of the abbreviations used in the paper are summarized in Table II.

[Nguyen et al.(2019)Nguyen, Marchal, Miettinen, Fereidooni, Asokan, and Sadeghi] FL for IDS in low power IoT devices IoT Activity, Deployment, Attack Data * Self- learning Anomaly Detection System for IoT devices. * Support of low Security Measures. * Low computation power * High Communication Latency
[Li et al.(2020c)Li, Zhou, Tu, Wang, and Zhang] Fl based IDS for various Computer Network TER20, SAT20 * Network Topology Optimization for Satelite Networks using FL * High Rate of False alarms
[Sun et al.(2020b)Sun, Ochiai, and Esaki] LAN Data * Segmented Federated Learning * High Energy Consumption
[Sun et al.(2020a)Sun, Esaki, and Ochiai] Distributed Network Data
references: In this section, the state-of-the-art review on FL for the use of anomaly-based IDS is exhibited. The practicality of FL architecture for the implementation of IDS is explored through key terms such as privacy, communication, data storage, and efficiency. A summary of the same is provided in table III.

S5.T4.caption: TABLE IV: Summary of Challenges and Future Directions for FL based IDS
S5.T4.table:
SL No Challenges Description Future Directions
1 Communication Overhead • High Communication Overhead due to transmission of model parameters to and from the clients each round. • Server bottleneck caused over handling of IDS systems based on a huge network of edge devices. • Binarized Neural Networks (BNN) are implemented in federated IDS systems for line-speed traffic classification and minimal latency [Qin et al.(2020)Qin, Poularakis, Leung, and Tassiulas]. • Modern Communication protocols like 5G and 6G are sought for better reliability [Fan et al.(2020)Fan, Li, Zhan, Cui, and Zhang]. • Asynchronous Federated Learning (AFL) methodology is proposed that ensures continuous communication and prevents central server bottleneck [Chen et al.(2020a)Chen, Ning, Slawski, and Rangwala].
2 Federated Poisoning Attacks • Manipulation of local client data and generation of poisoned data [Zhang et al.(2019b)Zhang, Chen, Wu, Chen, and Yu] • Plausible creation of backdoors in federated architecture for data poisoning attacks [Nguyen et al.(2020)Nguyen, Rieger, Miettinen, and Sadeghi] • Use of digital twin technology to ensure that solely intended data updates are used [Fuller et al.(2020)Fuller, Fan, Day, and Barlow] • Using blockchain based network transactions for the federated architecture to maintain secure transaction records. These transaction records assist in selective model aggregation preventing poisoning attacks.
3 High False Alarms through the use of non-IID data • High complexity, variance and ambiguity of federated data cause low convergence rate. • Data redundancy may result in model collapse. • Inefficient training due to above reasons of local and global model results in a high number of false alarms. • Hierarchical clustering techniques to combat the heterogeneity by grouping similar client weight update responses which simulates homogeneity. [Briggs et al.(2020)Briggs, Fan, and Andras] • Reinforcement learning techniques to fabricate an agent that rejects misleading weight updates due to heterogeneous data properties.
4 Resource Management in Low Power IoT Devices • In addition to have low support for security measures, low power IoT devices also have low computation and communication capabilities. • Minimal support for high end communication protocols may cause a system lag in the federated training procedure. • Efficient Resource Management, allocation and optimization techniques for better throughput and overall edge device performance [Ren et al.(2019)Ren, Wang, Hou, Zheng, and Tang]. • Implementation of lightweight ML/DL models for faster prediction speeds and lower computation costs [Latif et al.(2020)Latif, Zou, Idrees, and Ahmad].
5 Vulnerabilities in Intrusion Detection Setups • Continuous threat to the integrity of information assets protected by the IDS. • Difficult to classify new anomalous traffic, especially in an heterogeneous environment. • Utilization and implementation of Blockchain for secure communication between server and clients [Short et al.(2020)Short, Leligou, Papoutsidakis, and Theocharis]. • Introduction of digital twin technology in FL based IDS systems for better trustworthiness of FL architectures [Xu et al.(2021)Xu, Ali, and Yue].
6 Precise deployment of IDS • Huge pool of parameters that need to be fine tuned. • Slight deviations might not produce optimal results. • Manual tuning is time consuming and a tedious process. • Utilizing meta-heuristic optimization algorithms to tune the parameters mid-training. [Zhu and Jin(2019)]. • Reducing the overall number of parameters to provide fault tolerance.
references: After a critical review of FL-IDS systems and their challenges in the previous sections, the future scope of development in the field is discussed. Covering those issues, directions and possible solutions are provided for each. Considering the current literature and technological advancement on FL systems, many state of the art solutions seem feasible and applicable to the domain of IDS. Plausible solutions include the incorporation of modern communication protocols, encryption standards, blockchain, lightweight DL models, etc. A summary of the challenges faced, and their solutions proposed are presented in table IV.
